journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: The use of eigenpenalty parameters in structural stability analysis

article-meta.aff: Department of Structural Engineering, University of California, San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, CA 92093-0085, USA

abstract.p: In a recent publication, it has been mathematically proven that the eigenvalues of systems with constraints can be bracketed by replacing the constraints with positive and negative pairs of either ordinary or eigenpenalty parameters. This approach has already been demonstrated in the calculation of natural frequencies of systems subjected to both absolute constraints (such as supports) and relative constraints (rigid connections between multiple degrees of freedom). This study demonstrates that positive and negative penalty functions applied to the matrix associated with the eigenvalue can be used to enforce essential boundary conditions and rigid connections to determine the critical loads of linear elastic structures using the Rayleigh–Ritz procedure.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The penalty function method is widely used to enforce constraints in the solution of variational and differential equations. It was originally conceived by Courant [1] who proposed the idea of using springs of very large stiffness to model rigid supports in a Rayleigh–Ritz analysis. Until recently, it was thought that penalty parameters must be defined by a very large positive number. However, numerical results backed by mathematical theorems [2, 3] show that negative penalty parameters of very large magnitude are just as effective in enforcing constraints. This method has been used in computing critical loads [4], linear systems of equations [5], and linear stress analysis [6]. The convergence theorems show that the results of the models with positive and negative penalty terms approach the exact results with solutions converging monotonically from above and below, depending on the type of penalty parameter used in the solution as explained later. This property can be used to control the maximum possible error due to constraint violation in the penalty method and it is used in this study to check for numerical instabilities due to large values of the penalty parameters. The mean values of the results is a better approximation than those obtained using either positive or negative penalty parameters and half the difference between the two results gives the maximum possible error due to any violation of the constraints [4].

Furthermore, in Ilanko and Williams [7], a general mathematical proof has been presented to show that in a linear eigenvalue problem, positive and negative penalty terms can be applied to the system matrix that is associated with the eigenvalue. In their study, this type of penalty parameter is called an ‘eigenpenalty parameter’ and its application was limited to a vibration problem applying eigenpenalty parameters to the mass matrix. This article shows that the use of positive and negative eigenpenalty parameters associated with the geometric stiffness is useful in structural stability analysis. A tapered beam under axial compressive force and a two-beam frame were selected as test cases to illustrate the method.

In a paper by Andrade et al. [8], the Rayleigh–Ritz method (RRM) was used to determine the critical loads of a tapered I-beam, which were in good agreement with the results obtained using the finite element method (FEM). This study does not account for cross-sectional distortions as done in Andrade et al. [8] but only considers the overall lateral buckling, as the purpose is primarily to study the use of eigenpenalty functions to enforce constraints. In Andrade et al. [8], only functions that satisfied all geometric conditions were chosen as admissible functions. In this study, critical loads of tapered beams are obtained using the RRM to define the stiffness and geometric stiffness matrices of beams in free condition. Then, the penalty function method is used to define all constraints as well as to join the elements of the two-beam frame.

The use of eigenpenalty parameters has the advantage of needing lower penalty values, but also the disadvantage that the first mode is the last one to converge. Thus, the use of eigenpenalty parameters should be restricted to problems with relatively low number of degrees of freedom (DOFs) [9]. Otherwise, numerical instability due to very large eigenpenalty values may appear before the convergence of the first mode.

sec.title: 2 THEORETICAL DERIVATIONS
sec.p: Theoretical derivations for a tapered beam and a two-beam frame are presented in Sections 2.1 and 2.2, respectively. Theoretical derivations include in both cases the four types of penalty parameters that can be used to define constraints in stability problems: positive and negative artificial stiffness and positive and negative eigenpenalty parameters associated with the geometric stiffness matrix.

sec.title: 2.1 Tapered beam
sec.p:
The first example presented in this study analyses the equilibrium of tapered beams of varying second moment of area I(x) subject to an axial compressive force P, as shown in Fig. 1. The relevant second moment of area of the beam at the left end is denoted by I0. The beam is made of a homogeneous material of elastic modulus E and is of length L. The cross-section of the beam is taken as solid circular, with the variation of the radius of the cross-section given by (1) where r0 is the radius at the origin and rL the radius at the opposite end x = L. Fig. 1
Tapered beam under compression axial force constrained by spring elements
The second moment of area I(x) of the beam is (2)

The first step in the method to solve the stability analysis of beams and frames proposed here is to use the RRM with a set of admissible functions that model the deflection of a free–free beam [9] given below (3a) (3b) where n is the number of terms used in the set of admissible functions.
For a single structural unit, the amplitude of the displacement may be expressed by a single series W(x), as follows (4) where ci are unknown coefficients.
The potential energy of an Euler–Bernoulli beam due to bending is given by (5)
The potential energy due to an axial compressive force P is given by (6)

The second step of the method presented here is to add each constraint condition that is not satisfied by the set of admissible functions through the use of penalty functions. This may be achieved by including an energy term associated with an artificial spring of large stiffness or an eigenpenalty parameter into the total potential energy.
Then, the strain energy of artificial translational and rotational springs of very large stiffness kx and krx at a point x is given by (7)

For instance, for a clamped–clamped (CC) beam, four penalty functions are necessary to enforce the four required constraints. These include translational constraints at x = 0 and x = L as well as rotational constraints at x = 0 and x = L as follows (8) where the stiffness coefficients kx and krx serve as penalty parameters.

From the principle of stationary potential energy, the total potential energy of the structural system must be a minimum for a stable equilibrium. The Rayleigh–Ritz minimization with ordinary penalty term would be of the form (9) where the eigenvalue Pc is the critical load and Va *=Va/P is the geometric stiffness function, independent from the load.

The purpose of using large values for the penalty parameter is to minimize the value of the terms that are being multiplied by this parameter, thus constraining a DOF. This can also be achieved by including the penalty energy function as part of the geometric potential energy as well as with negative penalty values. In this case, the eigenpenalty terms associated with the geometric stiffness of the beam to model constraints at a point x are (10) where γ and γr are the eigenpenalty parameters in rotation and translation, respectively.
Therefore, the potential energy due to translational and rotational eigenpenalty parameters to model a CC beam is (11)

In this case, the eigenpenalty terms are multiplied by the axial force P in the same way the inertial penalty terms are multiplied by the square of the natural frequencies in vibration analysis. The derivations in Ilanko and Williams [7], although explained in the context of a vibratory system, are also applicable for structural stability analysis. The Rayleigh–Ritz minimization equation when penalty terms are added to the geometric stiffness to enforce constraints is (12) where Vg =Vg/P is the geometric stiffness penalty function, independent from the load.

For convenience, results are presented in a non-dimensional form. This is achieved by introducing a non-dimensional axial coordinate, dividing the stiffness and geometrical stiffness matrices obtained from the minimization of the terms defined in equations (5) and (6) by EI0/L3 and by 1/L, respectively, and introducing non-dimensional penalty parameters in either equation (8) or (11) depending on the choice of penalty parameter used in the solution. These non-dimensional parameters are defined as follows:
non-dimensional axial coordinate
(13)
tapering ratio
(14)
elastic translational and rotational non-dimensional stiffness penalty parameter
(15)
translational and rotational non-dimensional geometric stiffness penalty parameter
(16)

Then, the Rayleigh–Ritz minimization using artificial elastic springs and non-dimensional parameters gives (17) where K, G, and Ps are the elastic stiffness matrix, geometric stiffness matrix, and penalty matrix of elastic stiffness type, respectively, while c is a vector of unknown coefficients and λ the non-dimensional critical load defined as (18)
Similarly, if eigenpenalty parameters are used, the Rayleigh–Ritz minimization gives (19) where Pg is the penalty matrix of geometric stiffness type.
Then, the non-dimensional elastic stiffness, geometric stiffness, and penalty matrices are (20) (21) where (22) (23)
It is important to note that intermediate constraints on the beam can be modelled using either artificial stiffness (ordinary penalty term) or eigenpenalty terms using either equation (7) or (10).

sec.title: 2.2 A two-beam frame
sec.p:
The second type of structure analysed in this study is a simple two-beam frame consisting of two identical beams of length L and homogeneous material of flexural rigidity EI under a load P equally distributed on both beams. Each beam is fully constrained at the origin and joined to the other beam at an angle θ at x = L, as shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2
Two-beam frame under a compression force P

The procedure in this section starts with the definition of the energy equations of the system. These energy equations are given in the following order: potential energy of the beams due to bending; potential energy due to axial compressive load; energy to define inter-connection of the beams using penalty parameters; and energy to define boundary conditions. After all energy terms are defined, the Rayleigh–Ritz minimization is carried out to define the matrices of the system and then, the eigenproblem is solved with a specific set of boundary conditions and angle between beams θ.

In this case, the amplitudes of the displacement of the left and right beams are denoted by W1 and W2, respectively, and given by the following equations (24) (25) where the terms of the sets of admissible functions φi(x) are defined in equations (3a) and (3b).
The potential energy of the two-beam frame due to bending is (26)
The potential energy due to an axial compressive force P is (27) where P1 and P2 are the axial loads acting on the beams, as shown in Fig. 2.
Then, for symmetry (28)
The necessary ordinary penalty functions to define the inter-connection of two aligned beams as given in Yuan and Dickinson [10] are (29)

Thus, the DOFs at the end of both beams are fully coupled when springs of very large stiffness (positive or negative) are used to model the inter-connections, making the difference of the relative translation and relative change in the slope of both beams equal to zero. It is important to mention that in this case, the sign inside the second parentheses of equation (29) is positive because of the coordinate used (Fig. 2). Another relevant point is that when beams are joined to form a two-beam frame (θ ≠ 180°) instead of a stepped beam, it is necessary to include an extra translational penalty parameter modelling a pin at the joint. This is because the transverse displacement of beams at the joint is negligible when they form part of a frame, as their axial stiffness is substantially greater than their transverse stiffness. This effect holds for a large range of the angle θ between the beams shown in Fig. 2. The extra constraint can be added to either of the beams at the joint multiplying the translational penalty parameter at x = L by two, but in this study, the extra constraint is added to the first beam.
Then, expanding equation (29) and adding the extra constraint to model a frame (θ ≠ 180°) gives the penalty terms to define inter-connection of a two-beam frame (30)

It is possible to observe in equation (30) that without the extra constraint, the first and last penalty terms in translation and rotation are the same energy terms that could define boundary conditions at x = L on beams 1 and 2, respectively. The other two terms in translation and rotation define the coupling between the beams and define the off-diagonal submatrices of the stiffness matrix of the whole structure.
Boundary conditions at the origin of each beam are defined in the exact same way as in Section 2.1. Thus, the energy terms to define boundary conditions using artificial stiffness are (31)
Once again, the Rayleigh–Ritz minimization with ordinary penalty term would be of the form (32) where Va *=Va/P is the geometric stiffness function, independent from the load.

To define the two-beam frame problem in non-dimensional terms, some of the non-dimensional parameters in Section 2.1 are introduced in the solution. These are the non-dimensional axial coordinates defined in equation (13) and the non-dimensional penalty parameters in equations (15) and (16). To obtain results in a non-dimensional form, it is also necessary to divide equation (26) by EI/L3 and equation (27) by 1/L.

Then, after the Rayleigh–Ritz minimization of the non-dimensional system, the eigenproblem is defined as (33) where Ps,1, Ps, 2, and PCs,1-2 are the penalty matrices due to artificial elastic stiffness.

Following the same procedure to define constraints using eigenpenalty parameters will lead to the same penalty matrices after substituting the ordinary penalty parameter k∧ by the eigenparameter γ∧. This gives the following eigenproblem (34) where Pg,1, Pg,2, and PCg,1-2 are the eigenpenalty matrices.
In this case, the non-dimensional critical load is defined as (35)
Then, the non-dimensional stiffness, geometric stiffness and penalty matrices included in equations (33) and (34) are (36) (37) where (38) (39) (40)

Again, eigenpenalty matrices (Pg,1, Pg,1, and PCg) to be added to the geometric stiffness matrix are obtained in a similar way. These matrices can be defined by equations (38) to (40), if k∧ is substituted by γ∧.

sec.title: 3 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: The solution of the proposed method uses penalty functions to model constraints and inter-connections of the beam, which results in an asymptotic analysis to obtain the critical loads of the structures. In all cases, the monotonic convergence property is used to check for numerical instabilities. Results using either positive artificial springs or negative eigenpenalty parameters converge from below, while results using either negative artificial springs or positive eigenpenalty parameters from above (as the absolute penalty value increases). The structural stability analysis is carried out using positive and negative non-dimensional penalty parameters or eigenpenalty parameters with values equal to ± 10p, where p ∈ [1, 2, 3, …]. For each constraint added to the solution using a penalty parameter, the number of DOFs in the solution decreases by one. Thus, there is an eigenvalue that should be erased from the solution. These eigenvalues are very easy to identify as they converge towards ∞, - ∞, 0+, and 0- (as the penalty parameter increases its absolute value) for solutions using penalty terms representing positive springs, negative springs, positive geometric stiffness and negative geometric stiffeness, respectively. In addition, results obtained using eigenpenalty parameters include two rigid body modes, because the set of admissible functions used in this study model a free beam.

All sets of results presented in this study correspond to the set of results in which convergence up to the fifth significant figure was reached or to the last set of results before monotonic convergence was interrupted. Sets of results for all four types of penalty parameters converged to identical results up to the fifth significant number in all cases presented in this study.

sec.title: 3.1 Critical loads of CC tapered beam varying the penalty value
sec.p: This section shows the results of tapered beam cases. Results using the RRM and penalty parameters were compared with results obtained using FEM with standard beam elements as well as using Lagrangian multipliers in the RRM to define constraints in a similar way as in Klein [11]. In the penalty function method as well as in the Lagrangian multiplier method, the same set of displacement functions were used in the Rayleigh–Ritz procedure so that the effect of constraint violation would be the only cause of any discrepancy. For the same reason, all results were obtained from codes written for MATLAB, including the FEM results. In the FEM solution, each element used to build the tapered beam model has a constant radius, but the radius of each element decreases (for ρ∧<1) or increases (for ρ∧>1) as to have the same radius as the tapered beam at the centre of each element. It is worth to note that when Lagrangian multipliers are used to define the constraints of a system, the elastic stiffness and geometric stiffness matrices of the system increase by one row and one column for each applied constraint.

In this section, the convergence of the results for a CC beam with tapering ratio ρ∧=2 due to the penalty value is investigated. Table 1 presents the convergence of the critical loads with respect to the magnitude of the penalty parameters with solutions including 96 DOFs. It is worth to note that numerical instabilities occurred only when very large penalty parameters were used and were not found to be associated with the number of terms included in the series. Results presented in Table 1 confirm the predicted monotonic convergence depending on the type and sign of penalty parameter as explained in Monterrubio [9] and shows that lower eigenparameter values are needed to obtain converged results than when using ordinary type parameters. Table 1

All the results presented here for a single beam using the penalty function method regardless of the type of penalty parameter are identical to the results obtained using Lagrangian multipliers.

It is also possible to use fewer terms in the solution, for instance, fixing n = 10 (6 DOFs) gives a first critical load value with less than 0.5 per cent difference (148.45). However, the difference increases for higher modes.

sec.title: 3.2 Critical loads of clamped-simply supported, clamped free, and simply supported tapered beams
sec.p:
To investigate the use of eigenparameters in structural stability analysis further, beams with tapering ratio ρ∧=2 and clamped–simply supported (CS), clamped free (CF), and simply supported (SS) boundary conditions are given in Table 2. Table 2
Critical loads of CS, CF, and SS beams with tapering ratio ρ∧=2 using 96 DOFs
Penalty value Pc
Boundary conditions (bc) Method +k∧,-k∧,+γ∧,-γ∧ 1 2 3

RRM and Lagrangian
39.478 157.91 355.31
FEM
39.446 157.78 355.03

From the results in Table 2, it was observed that SS beams converged extremely rapidly for all types of penalty parameters. As in all other cases, when adding h∧ constraints, h∧ eigenvalues should be deleted from the set of results. It is very easy to identify these eigenvalues as they converge to 0+, 0−, ∞, or - ∞. However, in the SS case, it was detected that when using artificial stiffness, an eigenvalue converging towards ∞ or -∞, which had to be deleted, had not fully converged and was still ‘mixed’ with the valid eigenvalues when the penalty parameter was set to 10, which is the value given in Table 2. Results using higher penalty values show that these eigenvalues converged towards infinity.

sec.title: 3.3 Critical loads of CC tapered beams with 49 intermediate supports
sec.p:
The method presented in this study allows the application of boundary conditions at any point on the beam without having to change the set of admissible functions, which has been identified in the past as one of the most significant drawbacks when using the RRM [1]. However, when intermediate supports are used, more terms are needed to obtain results with the desired accuracy. To illustrate this feature of the method, results for a CC beam with 49 equidistant intermediate pins varying the number of DOFs are presented in Table 3. Table 3

sec.title: 3.4 Critical loads for two-beam frames
sec.p:
Table 4 presents results for two-beam frames attached at different angles obtained with the method proposed here and compared with results using the commercial FEM software ABAQUS [12] building the two-beam frames with 20 beam elements B32 (3-node quadratic beams). Penalty values on Table 4 correspond to the minimum value to reach convergence up to the fifth significant figure free of numerical instabilities. Results using the RRM were obtained fixing the number of terms in the set of admissible functions n = 20 for both beams. Table 4

sec.title: 4 CONCLUDING REMARKS
sec.p: It has been shown that positive and negative eigenpenalty parameters can be used to determine the critical loads of a constrained structure. Unlike the ordinary penalty parameter which corresponds to the application of an artificial elastic stiffness, the eigenpenalty is associated to the geometric stiffness term. The results obtained using a Rayleigh–Ritz procedure with penalty parameters were compared with results generated using the RRM and Lagrange multipliers as well as with those obtained by the FEM either using standard beam elements or the commercial program ABAQUS. Results of both methods using the RRM converged to virtually identical results. Numerical results show that convergence towards a constrained solution is obtained at a lower magnitude of the penalty parameter when using the eigenpenalty method compared to the ordinary penalty method. The use of the four penalty terms discussed in this study can help to obtain the error of the solution due to constraint violation while avoiding ill-conditioning and to reduce the number of analyses taking the average of the eigenvalues using a pair of solutions with two different penalty terms, one converging from above and one converging from below. The number of calculations can also be reduced, if the tolerance of the error is increased. Unfortunately, while using penalty parameters, calculations with a few penalty values must be made to check for convergence and ill-conditioning.

The set of admissible functions used in this study can be used to model the deflection of thin plates and shallow shells and the same method can be applied at least to symmetric structures built by plate elements under symmetric loads; otherwise, a pre-stress analysis must be also included in the procedure.

Another use of the penalty parameters not presented here is to add penalty terms to the elastic and geometric stiffness simultaneously, carefully selecting the ratio of the penalty/eigenpenalty values in a similar way as in the study by Askes et al. [13], where the value of the maximum eigenvalue was controlled through the value of the ratio of the penalty and eigenpenalty terms. The motivation in Askes et al. [13] was to avoid increasing the time step in time integration schemes that lead to higher CPU times for simulations. The use of the ‘bipenalty method’ described in Askes et al. [13] may also help if zero and infinite eigenvalues are to be avoided.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for profit sectors.
